timeline.body:
You call `currentNetworkStatus.get()` twice here, without any synchronization guards, it appears. What happens if the value changes between the two calls?

1. Do you need to add syncrhonization primitives?
2. You can defend by making one `.get()`, caching the result, and then using the cached result in both locations.
timeline.bodyText:
You call currentNetworkStatus.get() twice here, without any synchronization guards, it appears. What happens if the value changes between the two calls?

Do you need to add syncrhonization primitives?
You can defend by making one .get(), caching the result, and then using the cached result in both locations.

  2. You can defend by making one .get(), caching the result, and then using the cached result in both locations.

timeline.body:
In a microservice I did a couple years back, I found a pattern where you can add _behaviors_ to an `enum`. In that case, I would do like `Metrics.SOME_SERVICE_CRAP_HAPPENED.report()`.

But, you could use a similar mechanism here, potentially. Maybe something like:
```java
ApiEndpointStatus.UNKNOWN.announce();
```
And then have the hub broadcast logic contained inside the enum itself.
timeline.bodyText:
In a microservice I did a couple years back, I found a pattern where you can add behaviors to an enum. In that case, I would do like Metrics.SOME_SERVICE_CRAP_HAPPENED.report().
But, you could use a similar mechanism here, potentially. Maybe something like:
ApiEndpointStatus.UNKNOWN.announce();
And then have the hub broadcast logic contained inside the enum itself.
timeline.bodyHTML:
In a microservice I did a couple years back, I found a pattern where you can add behaviors to an enum. In that case, I would do like Metrics.SOME_SERVICE_CRAP_HAPPENED.report().

But, you could use a similar mechanism here, potentially. Maybe something like:

ApiEndpointStatus.UNKNOWN.announce();

And then have the hub broadcast logic contained inside the enum itself.

timeline.bodyHTML:
Aha!

We have this unfortunate situation with Hub right now, where we have to cast the data type.

I wonder if instead we can include a factory on the event structure, like:

ApiEndpointStatusChangedEvent event = ApiEndpointStatusChangedEvent.fromEvent(events.get(0));

Or, very similar:

ApiEndpointStatuChangedEvent event = ApiEndpointStatusChangedEvent.from(events.get(0).getData());

This would at least pull the cast into our own code where we can do it safely, without the customer needing to worry about it.

Impl might start off looking like an equals(....) almost:

public static ApiEndpointStatusChangedEvent from(Object someBlob) {
    if (!(someBlob instanceof ApiEndpointStatuChangedEvent)) {
        throw BadNewsBearsError("Shucks!");
    }
    ... etc. validate fields,
    return new ApiEndpointStatusChangeEvent(..., ...);
}
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText:
I created a couple of factory methods in each of the classes used as payloads for hub events. There's definitely some work to do in the Hub in general to make the approach cleaner. As it stands, the subscribe method definition takes a HubSubscriber instance which is currently just taking HubEvent<?> as a parameter which kind of prevents a cleaner approach to the problem.
TLDR: a cleaner approach would probably require changes to the Hub category definition.
replies.author: rjuliano
rjuliano

timeline.body:

```
NetworkStatusMonitor.enable();
```
Or something like that?

Also, does this _need_ to be int the constructor? Or could it go down into the `configure(...)` or `initialize(...)` hooks? Which is the most appropriate lifecycle hook for this?

timeline.bodyHTML:
You've got a mechanism repeated four times -- it's a signal to make it a data problem, instead:

List<DataStoreChannelEventName> expectedEventNames = Arrays.asList(
    DataStoreChannelEventName.REMOTE_SYNC_STARTED,
    DataStoreChannelEventName.READY,
    DataStoreChannelEventName.SUBSCRIPTIONS_ESTABLISHED,
    DataStoreChannelEventName.NETWORK_STATUS
);
Map<DataStoreChannelEventName, HubAccumulator> accums = new HashMap<>();
for (DataStoreChannelEventName eventName : eventNames) {
    HubAccumulator accum = HubAccumulator.create(HubChannel.STORAGE, eventName, 1);
    accums.add(accum);
    accum.start();
}

Or actually -- for extra credit, we could make a MultipleHubAccumulator utility, to get some of this boilerplate out of the test class itself.

It could accept a LinkedHashMap (to mandate and ordering in which to call await(). And have a usage pattenr like this:

// It's like a list of events, in order. Allows duplicates by Integer value > 1
// HubEvent1 --> 1 time
// HubEvent2 --> 1 time
// HubEvent1 --> 5 times
// etc.
LinkedHashMap<HubEvent<?>, Integer> tape = new LinkedHashMap<>();
MultiHubAccumulator accum = MultiHubAccumulator.create(tape);

accum.start();

accum.await(); // Waits for the entire "tape" to play.

timeline.body:
You could play a game here like:
```java
ApiEndpointStatuChangeEvent eventData =
    ApiEndpointStatus.REACHABLE.changeTo(ApiEndpiontStatus.UNKNOWN);
```

Basically, add afactory method to the enum, that has the ability to generate the change events. It knows the "from" based on what is being invoked, and it knows the "to", if we pass that as an argument.

timeline.bodyHTML:
Personally I agree with you that these are useful types of tests. However, I recently changed how I do this test, of the hashCode(). Rarely will anyone ever call hashCode(). Perhaps they will if they are writing their own, higher level hashCode(), and include one of these types in it. But more often, they'll probably try to use it in a collection. So like:

PossibleSaneHashObject one = new PossiblySaneHashObject();
PossibleSaneHashObject two = new PossiblySaneHashObject();
Set<PossiblySaneHashObject> set = new HashSet<>();
set.add(one);
set.add(two);
assertEquals(1, set.size());

This is straight-up pedantry at this point, feel free to ignore 😆
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText:
It makes sense...especially as we start adding more events down the road. That being said, the test itself seems pretty generic, so I created a class under tesutils called ObjectValidatorUtils. Right now it has one method that takes 3 objects: object1, object2, object3. The objects must be constructed such that:
object1.equals(object3), but not ==.
object2 is different from object1 and object3.
Let me know if this makes sense. Naming stuff is definitely not my superpower 🤣

timeline.body:
Oops, we want the `androidx` one here, I believe.

OkHttp uses the JetBrains annotations on its APIs, and so this probably got added when you implemented an OkHttp interface, right?

For better or worse, I have been _swapping_ such annotations, as I encounter them, into the AndroidX ones.

OkHttp is itself a vanilla Java library, so they _can't_ depend on the AndroidX annotations.

I feel emotionally that these annotations ought to have better support for Android Studio / Android Lint / Kotlin interop. However, I don't know it any scientifically backed objective way. 😆
timeline.bodyText:

timeline.message: Moved monitoring logic into a method

timeline.bodyHTML:
We have full liberty to add a new publish(...) method, if you would like to, as well!

Maybe like:

<E extends Enum<E>> void publish(HubChannel channel, Enum<E> eventName) {
    publish(channel, HubEvent.create(eventName));
}

A small optimization to reduce some boiler plate. I've already baked in some Enum<E> type mumbo-jumbo elsewhere around the Hub APIs.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: Oh...I will do that then. I think that will go a long way in cleaning some of this stuff up.
replies.author: rjuliano

replies.bodyText:
Well, turns out it's not as much on the publishing side as it is on the subscriber side. The HubSubscriber interface currently doesn't have a method that takes in a generic type. Modifying the existing one would probably make this a breaking change. Adding a new method to that interface would then force us to change every calling site from lambda-style to an anonymous object declaration. Neither of those sounded like a good plan.
Instead, I went with adding a factory method in HubSubscriber which makes the calling code a little cleaner.
replies.author: rjuliano
